metadata.title: Bio-dispersive liquid liquid microextraction based on nano rhamnolipid aggregates combined with molecularly imprinted-solid phase extraction for selective determination of paracetamol in human urine samples followed by HPLC

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Microchemical Journal
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/microc
Bio-dispersive liquid liquid microextraction based on nano rhamnolipid aggregates combined with molecularly imprinted-solid phase extraction for selective determination of paracetamol in human urine samples followed by HPLC Shahryar Abbasia, Seyed Ammar Haeria,⁎, Sami Sajjadifarb a Department of Chemistry, Faculty of Science, Ilam University, 69315-516 Ilam, Iran bDepartment of Chemistry, Payame Noor University, P.O.Box 19395-4697, Tehran, Iran
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Dispersive liquid Liquid microextraction Molecularly imprinted polymers
A B S T R A C T
An analytical method, molecular imprinting solid-phase extraction (MI-SPE) combined with bio-dispersive liquid–liquid microextration (Bio-DLLME), was established to extraction of the paracetamol from human urine samples. In this research, paracetamol was first extracted from urine sample into bioaggregates that composed of rhamnolipid biosurfactants as an extraction solvent. The clean-up of the extract by solid phase extraction was carried out by directly adding extract solution into the cartridge. The pH of the solution was adjusted to 8 using 50mM phosphate buffer. Finally, the analyte retained on the column was eluted with 1.0mL methanol and injected into the liquid chromatography system for quantitative analysis. This protocol significantly increased the recoveries and enrichment of the paracetamol. Under the optimize conditions, the proposed method provided a good linearity in the range of (1–200 μg L−1), low limits of detection (0.33 μg L−1) and quantification (0.96 μg L−1) and good extraction repeatabilities (relative standard deviations below 3.54%, with three replicates for each concentration value). The percent of the extraction recovery for paracetamol was 96–103.8%. The enrichment factor value of the extraction procedure was 368.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Paracetamol (N-4-hydroxyphenyl) acetamide is an effective alternative to aspirin and widely used medicines for the treatment of pain and fever associated with arthralgia, neuralgia and cephalagia. [1–3]. To study the paracetamol in biological samples, and to monitor the therapeutic concentration of its compound, it is necessary to develop highly sensitive and specific analytical techniques capable of determining the paracetamol [4–6].
Several analytical methods have been widely employed for the separation and quantification of paracetamol in biological samples, including gas chromatography [7], high performance liquid chromatography [8,9], and spectrophotometry [10,11]. All these methods offer many advantages such as the use of small volumes of organic solvents, high reproducibility, fast sample treatment and compatibility with most analytical instrumentation [12–15]. The goal of the sample treatment methods such as dispersive liquid-liquid microextraction (DLLME) [16] and continuous-flow microextraction (CFME) [17], is not only to
separate the target analytes from the samples [18], but also simultaneously to decrease or eliminate the hazardous materials which present in the pre-treatment process [19].
Therefore, the use of rhamnolipid biosurfactants, which have biological origin and reduce environmental degradation, in combination with dispersive liquid liquid microextraction could represent a novel strategy. In most cases, DLLME has been applied directly to water samples because is not a selective extraction method and interferences from matrix co-extractives are often present, especially for the determination of trace analytes in a complex matrix sample. Molecular imprinting polymers have artificial receptors with the memory of size, shape, and functional groups of the template molecules. The specific recognition ability of MIPs is based on the formation of complexes between the functional monomers with the templates. While there is no smart specific recognition ability in DLLME method. So this method is not selective. Increase the selectivity of the DLLME to reduce the matrix effects is crucial [20]. The aim of this work was to provide a new combination of two different sample preparation methods which
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.microc.2018.12.065 Received 26 September 2018; Received in revised form 28 December 2018; Accepted 28 December 2018
⁎ Corresponding author. E-mail address: haeriammar@yahoo.com (S.A. Haeri).
Microchemical Journal 146 (2019) 106–114
Available online 30 December 2018 0026-265X/ © 2018 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
T
decreases the influence of interfering compounds. The first step of the proposed method (Bio-DLLME) focused on the development of microextraction techniques based on biological agents which has already been successfully applied by our group [21]. Compared with the conventional DLLME, bio-dispersive liquid liquid microextraction (BioDLLME) technique is faster and more environmentally friendly that makes it suitable for current green chemistry trends. Also bioaggregates that formed in Bio-DLLME are more stable than a colloidal phase in conventional DLLME because rhamnolipid biosurfactants are active at extreme temperatures, pH and salinity as well [22–24]. After the first step, the solid phase extraction method was applied using molecular imprinting polymers to reduce or even eliminate the interferences originally present in the urine sample to facilitate selective extraction of paracetamol from bioaggregates. In particular, MIPs used as adsorbents of SPE have the ability of selectively isolating specific compounds or their structural analogues from biological, pharmaceutical and environmental samples due to having a specific molecular recognition ability which attributed to specific interactions between the template and the functional groups in the polymeric network. [24–27]. In contrast to traditional SPE adsorbents, such as active carbon, MIPs can be reused many times without losing its high selectivity and is more stable in harsh conditions (extreme pH and high temperature) [28–31].

sections.heading: 2.1. Chemicals and reagents
sections.text: HPLC-grade methanol and rhamnolipid biosurfactant were purchased from Merck (Darmstadt, Germany). Methacrylic acid (MAA), 2,2/-azoisobutyronitrile (AIBN), ethylene glycol dimethacrylate (EGDMA), ethyl acetate and acetic acid were obtained from (SigmaAldrich, USA). A working solution was prepared daily by appropriate dilution of the standard solution with ultrapure water that was double distilled and filtered by PURELAB Ultra (Organo, Tokyo, Japan) system. Chemical structures of the analyte and interference compounds are shown in Table 1.

sections.heading: 2.2. Instrumentation
sections.text:
Chromatographic analysis was performed with a HPLC (Knauer, Germany) instrument including a 20-μL sample loop and 2500 UV–Vis detector which was set at 254 nm wavelength for detection of the analyte. The detector temperature was 25 °C. Separation of the analyte was performed on reversed-phase C-18 column (4.6mm×250mm, 5 μm) from the MZ Analitical Company (Germany). Data were collected
and analyzed using the E.Z.Chrom (Japan) software. The mobile phase consisted of methanol (solvent A) and phosphate buffer (solvent B, pH 3). The elution program was isocratic conditions (70% A and 30% B). The flow rate of the mobile phase was set at 1.0mLmin−1. The molecularly imprinted polymer was characterized by Perkin Elmer Spectrum one Bv5.3.0 FT-IR spectrometer (Waltham, Massachusetts, USA) with KBr pellets. The morphology and dimension of the molecularly imprinted polymer was explored by scanning electron microscope (SEM) model VEGA TES-CAN (Brno, Czech Republic).

sections.heading: 2.3. Synthesis of the MIPs and non-imprinted polymers (NIPs)
sections.text: For obtaining stationary phase (MIPs) which demonstrate specific recognition ability to paracetamol in complex matrices, the precipitation polymerization technique was carried out [32]. Briefly, 0.5mL of paracetamol (0.2mmol) as template and 3.0mmol of methacrylic acid as a functional monomer were dissolved in 5.0mL of acetonitrile in a flask. After sonication this mixture for 10min in ice bath under stirring for 40min, 45mL acetonitrile, cross-linker and initiator agents (EGDMA 2.0mmol, AIBN 10mg) were added under nitrogen atmosphere. Then the polymerization reaction was carried out by incubating the solution at 80 °C for 24 h. The polymer particles were washed with a mixture of ethyl acetate and acetic acid (90:10, v/v) for three times with 10min sonication after polymerization procedure. The template was removed by this mixture and washed with methanol for two times to remove acid and dried under vacuum. Blank polymer (NIPs) were prepared based on this protocol without using the template molecule.

sections.heading: 2.4. Real sample analysis
sections.text: Applicability of the proposed method was investigated for analysis of urine samples that were obtained from patient and healthy individuals. All samples collected and stored in PTFE flasks at −20 °C until analysis. The frozen urine samples were thawed at room temperature and homogenized by vortex 5min at 1000 rpm. Then, 5.0mL of the urine sample was transferred into a clean tube and spiked at the two levels of concentration of paracetamol. The spiked samples were centrifuged for 10min at 5000 rpm in order to sediment white lipidic solid. The resulting upper layer was filtered through 0.45 μm filter and diluted 1:1 and 1:5, respectively, with ultra-pure water and 50mM phosphate buffer in order to adjust pH value. The results are listed in Table 2.

sections.heading: 2.5. Bio-DLLME procedure
sections.text: Human urine sample which prepared in the previous step was transferred to a 10-mL screw capped test tube. Rhamnolipid biosurfactant (35mg) containing methanol (500 μL) was injected into the urine sample by using a 1mL syringe and mechanically stirred (5min, 600 rpm) and then centrifuged at 5000 rpm for 5min to accelerate phase separation. Quickly, the stable structure of the bioaggregates consists of nano spherical droplets was formed and separated from bulk solution. Then resultant fine droplets were diluted with 2.0mL of acetonitrile in order to reduce viscosity. For the MISPE, the resulting diluted colloidal phase was injected into the cartridge.

sections.heading: 2.6. MISPE procedure
sections.text: To prepare MISPE column, a fixed mass (40mg) of the microspheres was packed into 1.0mL glass syringe (2 cm×0.9 cm i.d.). The corresponding NIPs were also fabricated with exactly the same method as described above. Before SPE run (analyte loading), column was pretreated with 2.0mL of acetonitrile and 5.0mL deionized water. After passing the sample solution with pH 8 (adjusted by 50mM phosphate buffer), the column was washed with 1.0 mL water for the elimination of impurities. Finally, the analyte retained on the column was eluted with 1.0mL methanol and injected into the HPLC system for quantitative analysis.

sections.heading: 2.7. Binding characteristic assays
sections.text: Batch adsorption experiments were used in order to investigate the binding properties of the synthesized MIPs to paracetamol. Polymer beads (20mg) were suspended in acetonitrile and added to a 10mL flask containing different concentrations of paracetamol (10–30 μg L−1). The mixtures were shaken in a rotary shaker at 25 °C and then centrifuged for 5min at 5000 rpm. The supernatants were filtered and free concentration of paracetamol was determined by HPLC-UV at 254 nm. The amount of paracetamol bound to the adsorbent was obtained by comparing its concentration in the MIPs samples to the NIPs samples. To show that the paracetamol is adsorbed on polymer, the same procedure was followed for NIPs particles.

sections.heading: 3.1. Characterization of the MIPs as SPE adsorbent
sections.text: The FT-IR spectra of the NIPs and MIPs are given in (Fig. 1). Fig. 1A is related to the FT-IR spectra of the NIPs after paracetamol removal. In Fig. 1B broad peaks at 3430 cm−1 and 3554 cm−1, can be attributed to –OH stretching vibration of monomer methacrylic acid. In addition, these absorption peaks appeared in the FT-IR spectrum of MIPs before (Fig. 1B) and after eluting of the adsorbent (Fig. 1C). A band at about 1610 cm−1 for unleached MIPs (Fig. 1B) showed the (C=O) group that assigned to the absorption peak of paracetamol. The results confirmed that host, guest binding between methacrylic acid and paracetamol were successfully achieved by the polymer synthesis method. The nitrogen adsorption and desorption profiles for the imprinted and nonimprinted polymers are shown in Fig. 2. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area and average pore size of MIPs were 71.21m2/g and 0.34 cm3/g, respectively, while these parameters were not obviously different from those of NIPs (55.68m2/g, 0.22 cm3/g). This observation means that adsorption properties of MIPs and NIPs were not caused by the morphological differences, but due to the imprinting effect of template molecule. Also, MIPs have a larger surface area and average pore size than NIPs due to the presence of cavities on MIPs.

sections.heading: 3.2.1. The effect of the type and volume of the dispersive solvent
sections.text: Dispersive solvent is selected based on its ability to produce a stable cloudy state. Considering the dispersive solvent features such as solubility with both water and the extraction solvent, acetone, acetonitrile and methanol was examined in this study. The results (Fig. 3A) indicated that among the proposed dispersive solvents, methanol had the highest extraction efficiency for the paracetamol than the other tested solvents due to the high dispersion degree of fine droplets. This result is due to the higher compatibility of methanol in aqueous solution. To prevent the change in the colloidal phase volume, a series of sample solutions included different volumes of methanol 200, 300, 400, 500, 600 and 700 μL containing 10, 20, 30, 40, 50 and 60mg of rhamnolipid biosurfactant were tested. The results (Fig. 3B) indicate that with the methanol volume increment (up to 500 μL) the extraction efficiency increases and, afterwards, it reduces as the methanol volume is increased. When the volume of methanol was lower than 500 μL, the cloudy state was not well formed. As well as rhamnolipid biosurfactant could not disperse well using the disperser solvent and subsequently, the extraction efficiency decreases. At high methanol volumes, extraction efficiency decreased due to the increase of the solubility of the paracetamol and the dilution effect of it.

sections.heading: 3.2.2. The effect of the type and amount of the extraction solvent
sections.text: The different kinds of extraction solvents were tested based on their capability for the extraction of the compounds of interest, their suitable dispersion in aqueous phase and good chromatographic behavior. Thus, chloroform, chlorobenzene, carbon tetrachloride and rhamnolipid biosurfactant were assayed as the extraction solvents. The experimental results indicate that the rhamnolipid biosurfactant has the highest extraction efficiency in comparison with the other tested extraction solvents. The extraction efficiency increase is due to the enhancement of the solubility of the analyte, and formed a well stable colloidal state. These results are closely related to the rhamnolipid biosurfactants amphipathic structure and their interactions with analyte through electrostatic and hydrophobic interactions. To investigate the effect of the amount of extraction solvent on the performance of the proposed method, extractions were carried out using 0.5 mL of methanol containing different amount (i.e., 25, 30, 35, 40, 45 and 50mg) of rhamnolipid biosurfactant as an extraction solvent. The experimental results indicated that as the amount of extraction solvent was increased, the analyte extraction efficiency was increased to 35mg, and then decreased as the amount of rhamnolipid biosurfactant was further increased to 35mg. This is because the concentration of the analyte in the bioaggregates decreased along with decreased enrichment factor. Thus, 35mg of rhamnolipid biosurfactant was considered as the best extraction solvent for further studies.

sections.heading: 3.2.3. Effect of pH and extraction time
sections.text:
Considering the chemical structure of the paracetamol (pKa= 9.5), the pH of the sample solution (especially about acid base species with active center) affects the binding interactions including ionic and hydrogen bonding interactions between the analyte and the adsorbent, and therefore influences on extraction efficiency. In order to determine the optimal pH range for the paracetamol extraction, various experiments were performed at different pH in the range from 1 to 13 (Fig. 3C). The highest extraction efficiency was achieved for the pH values between 5 and 9. At pH values below 4, methacrylic acid and paracetamol are in their protonated forms according to the pKa values (4.66 and 9.5 respectively) [33,34]. Therefore carboxylic groups of MIPs adsorbent could only interact with hydronium ions instead with the hydrogen atoms of the amino groups of paracetamol. As a result, the extraction efficiency is decreased. At a pH of between 5 and 9 paracetamol remain in the protonated form while methacrylic acid is in its anionic form. So, ionic interaction can occur between protonated
paracetamol and anionic carboxylate groups of MIPs adsorbent. At high pH (>9.5) paracetamol was turned into natural form, while methacrylic acid is in anionic form. High pH value leading to retention of the paracetamol onto the MIPs adsorbent based on hydrogen bonding which gave rise to lower extraction efficiency. According to experimental results pH 8 was chosen for extraction. In Bio-DLLME extraction time is defined as the interval between the addition of the bioaggregates to the sample solution, and before starting to centrifuge. In this study, the extraction time is shorter compared with conventional DLLME procedures because rhamnolipid biosurfactants as extraction solvent can decrease the interfacial tension between two immiscible fluids (extraction solvent: sample solution). By reducing surface and interfacial tension extraction equilibrium was achieved quickly and allow these two phases to mix and interact more easily consequently extraction time decreased. The extraction recovery was monitored by altering the extraction time from 0 to 200 s. The extraction recovery becomes constant after 40 s. Based on these observations, an extraction time of 40 s was used for subsequent experiments.

sections.heading: 3.3. Optimization of loading, washing and eluent solvents
sections.text:
In order to optimize the chromatographic separation, different parameters consisting of loading, washing and eluent solvents were
evaluated to achieve the best separation performance. Several solvents including dichloromethane, acetone, ethyl acetate and acetonitrile were tested as loading solvents. It was experimentally determined that highest extraction recovery was obtained when acetonitrile was employed (Fig. 3D). This behavior can be attributed to the fact that acetonitrile has a low effect on the hydrogen bonds between analyte and adsorbent, while the other protic solvents examined in this work could prevent the formations of these hydrogen bonds. According to these observations acetonitrile was selected as loading solvent. To eliminate the co-adsorbed matter in the matrix and increase the specific interactions between binding sites in the MIPs and paracetamol, different washing solvents were investigated to compare the performance kinds of washing solvent. It is important to ensure that the washing process decreased nonspecific interactions to avoiding interference of impurities. The best extraction recovery obtained when the water was selected as the washing solvent (Fig. 3. E). It was found that when methanol, ethyl acetate or acetonitrile were applied to wash impurities, extraction recoveries of paracetamol were below 50%. This is due to the formation of hydrogen bonds between ethyl acetate or acetonitrile with MIPs during the washing procedure and higher solubility of paracetamol in methanol. To achieve good selectivity and high recovery for the paracetamol, the elution step is the most important procedure in MIP-SPE. In this step analyte should be sufficiently desorbed from the
adsorbent. It is clear that nonpolar solvents could not adequately elute the paracetamol retained on adsorbent because they could hardly disrupt the hydrogen bonding between analyte and adsorbent. Therefore, polar eluting solvents (methanol, ethanol and acetonitrile) were utilized to elute paracetamol. The results showed the best elution efficiency (> 96%) was obtained using methanol as eluting solvent (Fig. 3F).

sections.heading: 3.4. Selectivity studies
sections.text:
The evaluation of the selectivity of imprinted polymer to paracetamol was carried out using sample solutions containing interference compounds at analyte:interference ratios of 1:10. 5.0mL of the mixture containing analyte and its structurally similar compound was added in a glass flask and solution was spiked at the three levels of concentration (100, 150 and 200 μg L−1) of naproxen (NP), ibuprofen (IB) and methadone (MTD) as interfering compounds. The extracted amounts were monitored by HPLC equipped with UV detector. The results showed that the synthesized MIPs adsorbents have high affinity as well as high extraction efficiency toward the analyte compared to NIPs adsorbents. The large selectivity coefficient values of the imprinted polymers are an indication of their high selectivity for the target analyte. This is due to imprinted cavities and specific binding sites of functional groups in a predetermined orientation. MIPs interactions with paracetamol are shown in (Fig. 4). At optimum pH (8) paracetamol will be protonated
while methacrylic acid is in its anionic form. So, ionic interaction can occur between protonated paractamol and anionic carboxylate groups of methacrylic acid. As a result, NIPs reveals a high affinity toward prcetamol over other structurally related compounds. On the other hand, carboxylic acid groups of naproxen and ibuprofen will exist in the anionic forms which does not benefit for adsorption. Electrostatic repulsion can occur between anionic carboxylate groups of methacrylic acid and anionic forms of interference compounds (naproxen and ibuprofen). Under these conditions, their extraction efficiencies decrease. For this reason, the selectivity coefficients of the naproxen and ibuprofen were larger than that of the methadone. Table 3 results indicated that methadone interference in the measurement of the analyte is greater than the other compounds. This result is attributed to the fact that methadone pKa value more closely related to analyte. In order to further investigate the recognition ability of MIPs over NIPs to the analyte, distribution coefficients (Kd) should be calculated.
= C C C V m K i f f d (1)
where Ci and Cf represents the initial and final concentration, respectively, V (mL) is a volume of solution, m (g) is a mass of adsorbent.

sections.heading: 3.5. Analytical performance
sections.text:
The linearity, recovery, limits of detection (LODs) and
quantification (LOQs), accuracy and precision of intra-day and interday were evaluated with the final method for real samples. Good limits of detection (0.33 μg L−1) and quantification (0.96 μg L−1) were obtained. Paracetamol was determined in urine samples accurately in a wide linear range of 1–200 μg L−1 with good squared regression coefficient (r2 > 0.99). For the recovery study, each human urine samples spiked at two levels and were used for validation of the extraction procedure. The data in Table 2 show that the relative recoveries of paracetamol were in the ranges of 96%–103.8%, demonstrating that the urine matrices had little effect on the proposed method. Limit of detection and limit of quantification were calculated on the basis of a signal-to-noise (S/N) ratio of 3 and 10, respectively. Intra-day and interday precision and accuracies were tested with triplicate analyses of samples spiked during the same day and in five successive days Table 4. The relative standard deviations (R.S.D.s) and accuracies were in the range of 1.2–3.7% and 98.0–101.9%, respectively. A comparison of the new Bio-DLLME based on nano rhamnolipid biosurfactants and the conventional DLLME method exhibited excellent performance of this newly-designed method Table 5. The combined technique has the advantages of the two techniques including better sample clean-up and
higher extraction recovery for determination of paracetamol compared to SBSE, DLLME and SPE methods alone. Although the two-step extraction process clean extracts, it has a number of drawbacks that limits its use, such as time-consuming and multistage operation. In comparison with SPE, MISPE eliminates matrix effects. Presence of cavities and specific binding sites of functional groups in a predetermined orientation in MIPs adsorbent highly improves the sample cleanup [41,42], which results in clean chromatograms even for extraction from the complicated matrix of urine. Bio-DLLME gave higher extraction recovery than conventional DLLME. This behavior is due to bioaggregates amphiphilic structure. There are hydrophobic, electrostatic and hydrogen bonding interactions among biosurfactants and paracetamol. These attractive forces attributed to the amphipathic structure of the rhamnolipid biosurfactants. Hydrophobic interactions can occur between paracetamol and rhamnose rings or a hydrocarbon chain of the biosurfactant. Electrostatic interactions can occur between protonated paracetamol and polar hydroxyl groups or oxygen atoms rhamnose rings. Also, hydrogen-bond forces increase the cohesion between analyte and biosurfactant. Types of interactions among paracetamol and biosurfactants shown in the Fig. 5.
a Dispersive liquid liquid microextraction, Molecularly imprinted polymer-solid phase extraction, Ultrasound-assisted ionic liquid dispersive liquid–liquid microextraction, Stir bar sorptive extraction, Solid phase extraction, Bio-dispersive liquid liquid microextraction-molecularly imprinted solid phase extraction.
b Acetonitrile. c Methanol. d Limit of detection for S/N=3 (LOD). e Linear dynamic range.
Nano bioaggregates can reduce the repulsive forces between two immiscible phases through reducing surface and interfacial tension and allow these two phases to mix and interact much more efficiently [43]. Also, nano bioaggregates have high adsorption capacity and large surface area-to-volume ratio, thus facilitating their contact with analyte and high extraction efficiency was obtained [44]. It was also observed that required extraction time of this process was less than other extraction methods. The time necessary to reach equilibrium can be decreased simultaneous with decreasing surface and interfacial tension to enhancing mass transfer. Therefore extraction of analyte can be achieved at shorter times. Fig. 6. show chromatograms obtained from the analysis of the human urine sample related to a person of paracetamol consumption (A), and same urine sample spiked with 50 μg L−1 of paracetamol (B), blank urine sample related to of a healthy person (C), and same urine sample spiked with 50 μg L−1 of paracetamol (D), using the Bio-DLLME-MI-SPE method under optimum conditions.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
In summary, we first demonstrated combination of dispersive liquid liquid microextraction based green nano rhamnolipid biosurfactants and MI-SPE as an efficient sample pretreatment method for the removes impurities and selective determination of paracetamol from human urine samples. A comparison of data obtained using Bio-DLLME as sample preparation method and those obtained using other extraction method, such as conventional DLLME and SPE showed the superior capability of the proposed method. Because the rhamnolipid biosurfactants possesses a high surface area and consequently a high loading capacity. Moreover rhamnolipid biosurfactants can increase the solubility of organic compounds through hydrophobic and electrostatic interactions. The combination of Bio-DLLME and MI-SPE as a two-step procedure enhanced the enrichment factor of paracetamol. The proposed method leaded to an increment of selectivity and sensitivity it
can be utilized for samples with complex matrices. The replacement of organic extraction solvent with biodegradable extraction solvent lets Bio-DLLME attain a stable cloudy state, rather than the conventional DLLME procedure.

sections.heading: Acknowledgements
sections.text:

Conflict of interest
The authors declare that there are no conflicts of interest.
Ethical standard
All procedures performed in studies involving human urine samples were in accordance with the ethical standards of the institutional and/ or national research committee and with the 1964 Helsinki declaration and its later amendments or comparable ethical standards.

referenceMentions.context: Several analytical methods have been widely employed for the separation and quantification of paracetamol in biological samples, including gas chromatography [7], high performance liquid chromatography [8,9], and spectrophotometry [10,11].

Nano bioaggregates can reduce the repulsive forces between two immiscible phases through reducing surface and interfacial tension and allow these two phases to mix and interact much more efficiently [43].
Also, nano bioaggregates have high adsorption capacity and large surface area-to-volume ratio, thus facilitating their contact with analyte and high extraction efficiency was obtained [44].

metadata.abstractText: An analytical method, molecular imprinting solid-phase extraction (MI-SPE) combined with bio-dispersive liquid–liquid microextration (Bio-DLLME), was established to extraction of the paracetamol from human urine samples. In this research, paracetamol was first extracted from urine sample into bioaggregates that composed of rhamnolipid biosurfactants as an extraction solvent. The clean-up of the extract by solid phase extraction was carried out by directly adding extract solution into the cartridge. The pH of the solution was adjusted to 8 using 50mM phosphate buffer. Finally, the analyte retained on the column was eluted with 1.0mL methanol and injected into the liquid chromatography system for quantitative analysis. This protocol significantly increased the recoveries and enrichment of the paracetamol. Under the optimize conditions, the proposed method provided a good linearity in the range of (1–200 μg L−1), low limits of detection (0.33 μg L−1) and quantification (0.96 μg L) and good extraction repeatabilities (relative standard deviations below 3.54%, with three replicates for each concentration value). The percent of the extraction recovery for paracetamol was 96–103.8%. The enrichment factor value of the extraction procedure was 368.
